text.headline: Early Evolutionary and Developmental Processes
text.text: Evolution of sexual dimorphism and gender differentiation, including the role of genes, hormones, and early sexual selection.

text.headline: Emergence of Primates
text.text: The earliest primates appeared around 55 million years ago during the early Eocene (Ni et al., 2013).

text.headline: Early Primates Social Structures
text.text: Early primates began developing social structures influenced by ecological and social pressures soon after their emergence (Hartwig, 2008).

text.headline: Gender Segregation in Early Primates
text.text: Gender segregation in social interactions, such as juvenile spider monkeys and rhesus monkeys, began early in life (Rodrigues, 2014).

text.headline: Sexual Selection Shaping Traits
text.text: Sexual selection mechanisms have been shaping gender-specific traits in primates since early evolution (Plavcan, 2001).

text.headline: Genetic Basis of Gender Traits
text.text: Modern genetics and epigenetics reveal how genes and the environment interact to shape gender traits (Salk & Hyde, 2012).

text.headline: Impact of Environmental Changes
text.text: Environmental changes, such as climate change and habitat destruction, play a significant role in shaping gender evolution (Zhu & Chang, 2019).
